reviewText:
It's Dynasty Warriors, and a good one, not much like it on the market. Either you love it, or hate it.

Seems to work ok with kb-controls. Almost impossible to use manual camera, but you can reset camera with block, and you can rebind keys. No mouse support, at all. Controller would be best I imagine.

Visuals, main-characters pretty good, but rest is pretty crappy, specially textures, but DW-games have always been on the weak side on visuals. Battles are huge tought, and it is fast paced game, so you don't have much time to hang around looking texture quality anyway.

Highly recommend enb graphical improvement for this game, check it online, makes game look almost nice.

reviewText:
As far as the game itself is concerned, it's like every other Dynasty warrior game, except for a few new characters and some slight changes to gameplay. However, if you are a long term fan of this series this wouldn't have come as a suprise. There is unfortunately NO online co-op, which is something that I've always wanted for this series. The controls are intitially really weird, and I opted for just using a gamepad instead of fumbling around with the keyboard.Graphics are pretty lackluster but that's never what this game was about right?

They added an enormous amount of weapons (specific wep for each character), and a new game mode. The new gamemode is a little boring in my opinion, but it's a nice change of pace from the regular story line. The best addition to this game has to be the alternate endings that are, non-historical, but much more fun to play out.

Overall would definitely reccomend this game to anyone who is new to the series and long-term fans alike.

reviewText:
Note: My earlier review was unfavorable for the following reasons, however I am now being favorable of this game:


*Problems*
-----------------------------
- Early release problems regarding controller rebinding. Also discovered that the game uses DInput rather than XInput, so some controllers will not work (like the Nvidia Shield Portable) without extra effort involved. If you buy this, make sure to have a fully working 360 controller or you will be dissapointed.

- No Network Multiplayer yet.


*Good Things*
-----------------------------
- It's Dynasty Warriors on PC.
- Ambition Mode is very fun, and does provide some break from grinding the campaigns over and over.
- Japanese VA available (this was added in as free DLC after release)


Should you buy it?
-----------------------------

I'd say in it's current form, yes, assuming you have a working 360 Controller and are a fan of the Dynasty Warrior series.


Should I buy the DLC?
-----------------------------

Not really. Most of it is rather wierd and gimmicky outfits with some new weapon types. The game already has a plethora of weapons so it's not really necessary.

reviewText:
Unless you are unable to get over the poor tutorials that don't bother to label buttons, the fact that certain actions are linked together in ways that prevent easy button mapping, and the fact that enemy variety is not exactly a thing here, this game is amazing.

Providing enough content to last over 70 hours with a large pool of distinct and colorful characters and a story that's somehow a bit more interesting than you might think, this is well worth its price tag.

While several other games out there involve hacking and slashing through swarms of enemies, the Warriors series continues to be the best of this bunch. While this means you're not buying the most complex of plots, the best in voice acting, or the skillful of combat systems, if all you need is something interesting enough to unwind with, with combat that feels right and flows wells, then you need this in your library.

reviewText:
Bought this game on a summer sale, and if you did the same, you will not be disappointed.

For the Dynasty Warriors veterans out there, this game continues the upward climb back to goodness since the dastardly downfall that was Dynasty Warriors 6.  For new players, this game offers interesting fighting gameplay mixed with you personifying a character in history.

PROS:
The weapon system - Each character has proficiencies with different weapons, ranging from 1 to 4 stars.  You are able to use whatever weapons you want as your primary and secondary weapons, but it would be wise to stick to the ones you are proficient with.  Personally I find this system to not be worth much and stick to the weapon meant for the character (their 'Ex' weapon).  So, for example, Lu Bu, I use two helberds, one for primary and another for secondary.
The levels - I like how they decided to add Hypothetical routes to the story modes.  Granted these maps are largely aww lets all come together and win yayyyyy" maps
date:
but one could take the historical value in that these battles would happen should the path have been taken in history.

The rest of the gameplay is typical of Warriors games and can be watched on youtube for 5 minutes and understand what its about.

CONS:
Graphics - Why they decided to port the PS3 graphics of the game is beyond me
recommended: and whoever decided to do that should be slapped.  Having played this on the PC and then seeing the PS4 graphics
hoursPlayed: it drove me to buy the PS4 version of the game and replay my progress there.  One caveat that I had not considered was that my game looked much better if I turned the brightness settings all the way up!  Strange...  Graphics comparison videos are available online.\nCharacter design - While I
voteText: and many others appreciate a dub to accompany the subs with the option to go back to Japanese voices
helpfulPercent: some of the English voices are just terrible.  For example; Jiang Wei's voice is bad
votesHelpful: and Sun Quan's is not well done but tolerable.  There are also token words that get very old very fast
votesTotal: such as Jiang Wei/Liu Chan's overuse of the word "Benevolence".  I also dislike how they are morphing many of the characters to look like they are ripped right out of an anime
votesFunny:
but I guess we have the otaku kawaii culture that Koei caters to in Japan to thank for that.


All in all: For the new fan a suitable game to try
commentsCount: if you can get it on sale.  For those that have been playing for awhile

reviewText:
I have been a fan of Romance Of The Three Kingdoms ever since Dynasty Warriors 2 and it's been a different experience in every release, despite the fact that the franchise is built upon the same Three Kingdoms era in China (around 200 AD).
You play as one of the renowned officers serving your kingdom (faction in some cases), throwing yourself into the battlefield and ready to give thousands of foes some whipping lessons.

So it's just a hack 'n slash action game?
Yes, and beyond that as well. Depending on the weapon you choose, you'll get a different moveset to negotiate your way to your enemies' elimination (me and my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ rhetorics) and it all gets spectacular in new ways whatever you pick.

But all I am doing is just beating up enemy soldiers to win each battle?
Yes and no. Granted, many of the scenarios' outcome are decided upon whose commanding officer gets defeated but there are other kinds of critical objectives taking place, as well. One I can think of is escorting an important officer to safety out of the battlefield, which means you'll have to fight those who stand in the path and putting the mission into jeopardy. (that's the point, after all)

Every scenario also have a set of different events that will decide the flow of battle and it is up to you if you will carry them out for the benefit of your current scenario or the next one. So the strong point being is that it all comes to strategizing your next move. (like, should you carry out that side objective or protect your commanding officer from incoming attacks?)

Outside the gameplay factor, I must say that the developers have allowed to lift up the character's personalities throughout the story, giving them some kind of intrigue value since you can relate with some of them. Cao Cao, for example, has been relatively portraited as some kind of villain at different points but playing the Wei campaign shows that there are different nuances that defines his human values.

By what I've summed up so far, Dynasty Warriors 8 comes up with different gameplay functions and character designs (both in looks and moves) on a familiar preset based on the Chinese history. Having not played anything since DW5, this was a welcoming return when it has made its way to Steam and it's hard to quit when I've gotten into the rampaging and progressing through the battlefields and stories. I haven't tried other game modes such as Ambition mode, but you can find other reviews that touches upon those contents. Ever since Dynasty Warriors Online went down, I (as many other fans) only wished the online multiplayer function would come back again on this release but I can only hope it does someday soon.

reviewText: This being my first dip into the series since Dynasty Warriors 4 way back on the PS2 I was surprised by how similar this edition was. It has the same button mashingly brilliant action, a roster bigger than Lu Bu's biceps and classic battles to recreate however, I noticed that some features appeared to be missing. Considering we are now entering a new golden generation of online play, why no online multiplayer? Yes it does have split screen co-op but I can't imagine this will appeal to many working with a 19 or smaller monitor. reviewText:
I started playing the franchise at DW3, which would eventually be done so on a near religious level, almost all the available characters stats were maxed out by the time I stopped playing it.  I also had the chance to put in at least a few hours for DW4, and DW5.  I haven't gotten the chance to play DW6, or DW7, so if my review mentions features that were already present you'll know why.

First things first.  Lots of people complain that it is a bad port.  IT'S NOT.  Many users had some issues before I had even purchased a copy, it had to do with multi-core usage I believe, but that's all been fixed.  I have a mobile GTX 500 series card and can play this game at full settings with fluid gameplay.

Pros: I liked having the ability to have two weapons in the battle at once, so I wasn't stuck with a single weapon the entire time as some battles can last up to 45-60 minutes.  There's also plenty of more NPC's on screen.  I used to think killing 1000 units was a big deal but the other day I finished a battle with more than 3000 units dead and didn't think it took too long.

I also enjoyed the inclusion of ranged weapons as an ACTUAL weapon rather than just a side-weapon all characters received.  The aiming in DW3 will not be missed.  The ghost horses that you can summon out of nowhere is kind of odd as well but I'd rather have a ghost horse than run my ♥♥♥ around the entire map for 8 minutes.  While online multiplayer is not included, local co-op is! So grab a second controller and invite someone over to play with you.  And have you tried Huang Gai's new weapon?  It's a god damn boat.  Water pops out of nowhere and he slides on his boat in the middle of a battlefield.  Some of the weapons even float now, which I wasn't used to, but there's always been magic weaponry so why not.

Cons: The most annoying thing for me was mapping the controls to my controller because the default settings were kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for me.  I made the button scheme almost exactly the same as DW3 minus/plus some features, and that can be achieved in just a few minutes.   I also miss the quick cut-scenes for introducing characters, and for when they die.  And I feel like some of the custscenes in-between battles are drawn out too much, as if they say a lot but have nothing to say.  Otherwise this is just a more polished DW with more characters, more weapons, and more ways to play.

Things that need to happen:  GIVE ME DW8 EMPIRES

reviewText:
One of the better DW installments in my opinion. The historical and hypothetical routes gives you pretty much every scenario ever imagined so far for the series. Ambition mode is pretty interesting and really adds to the replay value. 5th and 6th weapons are for the most part a challenge to get so collectors have plenty to look forward to. I'm just really irked that they didn't include the original Japanese audio for this one. I've had it in previous DW games on consoles but for some reason they just decided not to include it.

I would definitely recommend this title to any DW fan. To those who are new to the series: It's a glorified hack'n'slash, set in the Three Kingdoms era of feudal China(following the story of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms). If that's the kind of game you enjoy, I also recommend this to you.

BREAKDOWN:

The story is given in various formats. Cinematic cutscenes are used to tell some more dramatic moments, while the stories of the battles themselves are told during gameplay through dialogue. Exposition and time skip filler story is presented in visual novel format. The story itself is, of course, the Romance of the Three Kingdoms. If you've played any other DW game before, you know what that means. If not, then honestly the DW games are probably the best way for you to experience that story.

Audio is standard DW, which is both a pro and a con. A pro because it's very concise and action packed, from SFX to BG music, so the audio really adds to the impact of the game. A con because it literally has not changed since like, PS2 days. The audio is more high definition, sure, but those death screams are the same death screams I heard as a child, slaughtering thousands of hapless Chinese peasants.

Gameplay is standard of a DW game. No weird gimmicks in this one like they've experimented with before, just pure and simple attacking, blocking, parrying. However, with the game's cast of 50+ playable characters, each with their own unique weapon, the gameplay can remain fresh for quite some time if you change up who you are playing or what weapons you are using.

EDIT: I forgot to mention the one new thing they did add this installment, which is the Weapon Attunement system. Basically it's a rock/paper/scissors(or in this case Heaven/Earth/Man) system where certain attuned weapons do more damage to and allow for storm rushes against enemy officers using an attunement that is weak to yours. You are allowed two weapons and the game(and I) recomment using two different attunements in order to prevent enemy officers from having an attunement advantage.

Graphics are... console port quality. To be fair, I doubt the studio ever put a lot of attention into the peons in the first place, but they look like clay soldiers when they do close ups of their faces. The officers themselves are much more defined, and they actually look good. It's also not very optimized to run in 1080p(which is an option on the PC version). I have a pretty beefy rig but I still notice huge frame drops when I first load a mission for seemingly no reason. It smooths out quickly though and will stay running smooth until the next time I launch the game.

OVERALL:
I'm leaning on a 7.5/10 for this one. Really is a lot of fun, but I think it's a very niche game.

PS:
About the multiplayer thing: It's been my experience that DW has never had online co-op. It's always been local co-op, so not sure what to say about that. I'm not sure if they will ever do online co-op for a Musou game so don't expect it to be a thing for this one.

reviewText: Note: You should play this game with a controller if possible. It will make the experience MUCH better.\nAt first, I was a bit apprehensive of buying this game. Although I am a longtime Dynasty Warriors fan, I heard terrible things about the port for Dynasty Warriors 6, and read some meh things on the port for this game + lack of online multiplayer. Plus, I didn't know if my lapop could run it. However, I am happy that I purchased this game. This game has a TON of content. When I say a ton, I mean you have 5-6 campaigns, free mode, challenge mode, and ambition mode. The game is another step in the right direction towards making great Dynasty Warriors games, and I would put it up there with the best in the series.

reviewText:
Finally, I can satisfy my hankering for some Dynasty Warriors hack n' slash action on PC!!

I will admit that I haven't been following the series the whole time, but I've played Dynasty Warriors 3 and a little of 4, 5, and 7. I did not like 7, and my hopes weren't very high for this game, but let me tell you...awesome!!!

Pros:
Brought back correct weapons - I remember in 7 that Xiahou Dun had a two handed mace, where as every other one he had a scimitar. He has the scimitar again! And other fixes like that.
Long Campaign mode - you play by faction, not by character, which I like because you get to try out different characters and the story is much longer and it doesn't get as repetitive. Each level gives you 2-4 characters to pick from.
Weapon Customization - while it may be a little cheap, every character has 2 weapons that they can switch between in battle. Some weapons are more compatible with the warrior than others (rated 1-4 stars). So even if you find a weapon that you really like, it doesn't make sense for ALL of your characters to use that weapon. And every warrior has a specialty weapon that they are supposed to use, but you can change it.

Cons:
Graphics - there is nothing really special about the graphics, and I see some graphical flaws here and there (lines across the face, etc.) but it doesn't stop me from playing.
Plot holes - I remember fighting Zhang He in one battle and the next level he was on my side. What happened? Why is he my friend now?
Other usual bugs - I killed Diao Chan. Lu Bu got angry. The English message said Diao Chan is enraged at Lu Bu's death" (something along those lines)
Controls - the default controls for the Xbox Controller are my biggest problem. I had to remap them completely because none of it made any sense. And I HATE that the musou button and OK button are the same mapping
date: because I use B for musou and OK should be A
recommended: so now whenever I want to confirm something it's B
hoursPlayed:
and cancel is A...

Overall -
I can get used to the controls
voteText: though they are annoying. Everything else is not a dealbreaker to me. I've already put 8 hours into the Wei campaign and I love it."

reviewText: May not convert long-time critics or win over completely new fans with what appears to be nought but shallow button-mashing-for-victory gameplay (something which isn't actually true at all, especially if you play on higher difficulties), but for the fans the Warriors franchise remains a lot of fun and this installment is no exception. DW8XLCE offers series veterans exactly the sort of battlefield rampages they want from the franchise. The amount of content within this package is incredible, but the DW series has always been one which seems to pack a hell of a lot of stuff in with every release. Just make sure you have a controller of some sort, because this is a game which is certainly NOT designed around keyboard-playing!

reviewText:
It's hard for me to objectively review a Dynasty Warriors game, seeing as I have been a pretty hardcore fan since Dynasty Warriors 2 on the PS2. That said, this is probably my favourite of the series, dethroning previous favourite #5. I already had the original Dynasty Warriors for the X-Box 360, but I picked up the Steam version to get the Xtreme Legends content, which otherwise was only released on PS3/4.
Anyway, this is the sort of game where you're either a fan, or you're not. If you like massive battlefields where you can slaughter hundreds (or in some stages, thousands) of lesser enemies, you've probably played Dynasty Warriors before and have a feel for what the game is like.
As far as the series is concerned, this game has loads of characters and a pretty complex storyline for all the major factions. Graphics are polished, and voices are decent - the appropriate balance of serious and stupidly over-the-top. Also, the Ambition Mode is about 296.8% better with the expansion than the standalone game.
My only serious gripe (and it *is* a pretty serious one) is that there are some serious problems with the in-game movies - many players, myself included, have experienced crashes whenever the game tries to play a movie (like when the game first loads!). This is resolved by disabling movies via the configuration menu, but then you're missing out on those badass opening and end-of-campaign movies that the series has always been known for.
Overall, though, a very solid purchase for a Dynasty Warriors fan.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To begin, I would like to make a note of the small play time: I recently got this on PC after spending a good deal of time playing this on Sony's many chain of consoles, and absolutely love it there. I can't give you an exact number of hours I've spent on the games up to this point as that requires me to go back over 3 consoles worth of data, both saved and deleted, but it's at over 200 hours, if not 300.

Dynasty warriors 8: Xtreme Legends. The game that brings the franchise to PC outside of the online arena of DW:O. If you like mindless hack and slash action, then yes, you will love this. However, the developer himself has stated that this game has been made to hurt that mind set, rewarding tactical play and supporting your allies. If you know anything about Koei's Warriors series of games, you know this game.

Character choice has never been greater, with the establish stories with the Kingdoms of Wu, Wei and Shu, fighting over China, 7 Brought in the tale of the historical victor, Jin, led by the Sima, and this title brings the Ahistorical tale of Lu Bu, stated as the protagonist of this game. Character count has increased to 87, going up from 82 in the normal edition.

Whilst every character has a unique move set, this is only because they all have a unique weapon they are associated with. Every character can use every weapon in game, with a varied degree of skill. This is not a bad thing, it allows players who are trying to get used to a move set a safety net if they find that they can't get used to it. However, this brings in the downside of this. Whilst I'm all for unique looking weapons, a few of them are too.....fantasy based for the era this game is set in. I'm all for magic being used seeing as we have this being a major thing in the game, I don't see why they should have equipment that's associated with modern day equipment (don't believe me? check the Siege Spear)

The main story of the game has been changed from how it normally works. Dynasty warriors 4 brought in kingdom play, a style that hasn't been repeated nor explored since. this game gives you a selection of characters to use per battle and you have to pick one of them. They tend to vary, and the characters you pick are all the ones that have a major event occur involving them, along with all having a varied move set. You will never have a battle where all the available characters have a move set that is related to another style. You will also find that each character has their own role in the battle to come, allowing you to follow that path for them and watch the events unfold.

Not only that, but the game also has, what it deems, a hypothetical route that you can take. Should you fulfil certain requirements, the next battle, or even events of the current battle, may change, allowing you more options later on. Like Aid in a later battle or the opportunity to turn back the tide. Each kingdom has two endings to it's normal route, the historical and the Hypothetical. What the Xtreme edition of the game brings in it is another third tale, one regarding Lu Bu and his story. These have their own battles and their own themes.

Ambition mode is a sort of endless battle type game mode. you fight several battles in order to expand your home base with supplies, manpower or just to become famous.  Whilst the game doesn't go much into it in the base version, simply ending after you have built a palace, the Xtreme edition carries on, making it so that you attempt to unite China for the Han through fighting alongside your allies and making friends with them. Challenge mode returns, and the bodyguard system returns, allowing you to bring three allies into battle.

The game looks amazing considering it's roots on consoles, and it is good to see that it makes it's run on PC. if you do buy this game, I recommend you play it with a controller. I'm not saying that the game is impossible to play with a keyboard, but you will find it a lot more comfortable to be able to sit back with a controller and relax.

The story of the game is there, however, it is limited. Let's face it, your there for the game, not the story. However, there is enough development to give each character a personality and be more then just a character, but don't rely on it to carry you through. It's enough to give each battle context and to cover a few major events.

If you like games that just let you sit back and hack your way through enemy soldiers, you will like this game. If you like to be able to do that with a slight tinge of tactics to it, then you'll enjoy it. However, don't buy this game if you are expecting a tactical hack and slash title. what Strategy there is is limited to who you should take down and where you take the fight.

reviewText:
It's better than DW7. More characters, more weapons (even though a lot of the new ones are just stupid and don't fit the setting). Also the campaign missions are a lot more in-depth than they were in DW7.

Ambition Mode is fun for a while. Good way to level your characters so that you can actually stand a chance on Chaos difficulty.

This game still has bugs though. Be cautious when playing as Jia Xu in the campaign. Almost every time I play as him in the campaign, the game crashes... :'C

I give this game a 9/10, but I love DW so I'm probably more forgiving than most.

reviewText:
This first time I saw a review for this game, I wasn't excited, the ideia of kill hundreds of enemies with a single blow wasn't great for me. I thought it was a single button smasinhg.

But, for my surprise, I was wrong. The fighting is surprisingly deep (try to juggle an enemy for 5 secs non stop for the first time and you will understand) and incredibly hard in latter difficulties, forcing you to think before smash the buttons.

The game is HUGE too, so many little things to discover and open, and not to talk about the 82 differents characters with different weapons and play styles, making each one of them fell unique.

Definitely worth the investment, even at full price.

reviewText:
This game is great!
Pros: No online multiplayer, just local so that me and my buddy can play together!
English dubbs! (I can't understand Japanese, why do i care?)
No real attempts at trying to be an accurate war sim!
Somehow makes being unstoppable fun for more than 5 min
Runs AMAZING (probs from that low tex qual rofl)

Cons: Too much shine and glitter, it's hard to see what's going on sometimes and i feel TOO much like a god. (7's where it really started i think)
Controller mapping (my god...)
All characters come unlocked, so there's not the fun of finally unlocking LuBu and knowing you can't lose anymore.
some of the textures (most are great, there are just a couple bad ones that are too blatantly obvious)

Overall 10/10, game hasn't made me this happy in awhile, i actually can't wait to get home and play it. And im an adult!

As a long time Dynasty Warriors fan (from ps2's first release and onwards), I was a bit hesistant to pick up DW8 based on some of the steam reviews.  However, after playing the game myself, I can assure you: THIS IS THE BEST DW8, yet!

Let me begin by retorting some of the other reviewer concerns:

-This is indeed a port from the PS4

-Everything looks great.  The character's have amazing detail and their Mosou moves are brilliant/vibrant and addicting to pull off.
- The sound quality is excellent.  Even the cheesy dialogue :)

The lack of online co-op"  is no reason to downvote this game. It's still amazing without it.  And longtime fans

reviewText:
8/10

I first came into the DW franchise back at DW5 on the ps2. I loved it and dumped hours into the game. Having played this game for a bit, I can safely say that i really feel the familiar feeling returning and i think its great. However, I have two nagging gripes...

1) No individual character storylines. Even though you'd often play the same level numerous times, only starting at different spots, it was still nice to follow a character you enjoyed and help orchestrate who they would become in DW5. Sun Ce is one of my favorite characters, and i was a little dissapointed when i only got to play him for 3 or so missions.
2) Character name pronunciation. Now, i don't know if this is just my mind forgetting, or if the name's changed at some point, but i remember Sun Ce being pronounced Soon-say, and Cao Cao being cow-cow. I just feel a little annoyed whenever i hear their names now

reviewText:
I am eternally grateful to my friend introducing me to Dynasty Warriors 3 back in 10th grade of high school. Since then, I have been a huge fan of Dynasty Warriors (as well as the Three Kingdoms story in general), and have fond memories of he and I playing DW4 latenight during summer vacation - literally every day until 3am (and a morning break in which he would go home, shower and return 4 hours later for more Dynasty Warriors. The joys of a carefree teenager).

I stuck with the series all the way, though burned out on it with DW5 and was disappointed with DW6. I'm still a huge fan though, and I wasn't disappointed with DW7, which renewed my interest in the series. Sadly, shortly after its release, my console bit the dust. Of course, in the end, this was a good thing as it was the driving force to my wife buying me my first ever gaming PC. Alas, no DW7 (outside of jacking a glitchy and entirely foreign JP copy), and I figured my Dynasty Warriors fanaticism would be stuck in the past as memories of the good ol' days.

Thankfully, Koei decided to release DW8 and its XL expansion to Steam as the Complete Edition
date: despite actually lacking a number of DLC packs available on the console version (though I've heard DLCs are on the way). And now that its been released, gamers are crying foul!" at every turn for various reasons. So with all that in mind
recommended: and a bit of knowledge as to my background with playing DW games
hoursPlayed: let's get to it.\n\nFirstly and flatly
voteText: do I recommend this game? Absolutely
helpfulPercent: yes. The game plays like any other Dynasty Warriors game - pick a guy (or gal)
votesHelpful: insert person into a battlefield and go to town on the enemy. It's repetitive button mashing at its finest. The series has received the alternate title of "Chinese Genocide Simulator
votesTotal:
and this game lives up to that moniker. The first story battle, I used my favorite Wu character, Shangxiang, and plowed through 1600+ people before the map was done (on normal difficulty). It was possible to get 1000 kills in DW3 thanks to the never-ending populating gates, which required the death of the gatekeeper before they stopped spawning enemies, but DW4 toned it down and 1000 kills generally required a higher leveled player and a lot of goofing around. As I said, DW5 burned me out - it wasn't very memorable for me, as with 6, so I don't recall how easy it was to hear your character proclaim themselves a true warrior of the three kingdoms. But for me to get 1000+ kills on the very first level with an unleveled-up Shangxiang was a sign of good fortune regarding this game.

Your character can use any weapon in-game, but excels with certain ones, and of course is most proficient with their own personal weapon. You can have multiple musous stored up, and so on and so forth. Basically, the gameplay does add on to what the later renditions gave to the series, so its not like you might as well be playing a graphically improved version of DW2 or 3.

Speaking of graphics, this is another spot where many gamers are angry. The pictures provided in the DW8 store page are apparently screencaps from the PS4 version of this game, but the in-game graphics are PS3 quality, or perhaps a slight step above.  Certainly it appears Koei is guilty of fibbing, but honestly I just can't get angry - graphics don't mean a whole lot to me, and although it would be nice if they looked better, I can still go back and play DW3 right this moment and not have an issue with its block hands and hard-edged polygons. In other words, unless you absolutely NEED the very best you can possibly get, the graphics in this game look fine.

Sound-wise, I haven't heard anything terrible, which is both a good and bad thing. The music in the game offers a variety of songs from previous games, including the more memorable ones from DW3 and 4. This is always a welcomed addition. Unfortunately, I haven't heard any outstandingly bad dubbing. One of the things that makes DW3 such a great experience, then and now, is its terrible voice acting. I won't list them here, but a quick search in YouTube can help you find cutscenes with some of the most hideously read dialogue ever produced. I'm one of those guys who likes it that way, and I've never had an issue with the English dialogue in any of the games. Sadly for me, the voice acting has improved considerably over each rendition of this game, and although some characters in DW8 do not have a well-fitting voice (compared to previous incarnations), it's not bad enough to be memorable like You flaming idiots" or "Yuan Shu
votesFunny: you have deceived me!"\n\nAnother gripe from the community is the controller support
commentsCount: or lack thereof. I've heard everything from the game not recognizing 360 controllers to default inputs totally dismantling typical controller layout. I can only report on what I've experienced

reviewText:
The pure Dynasty Warriors experience in a suprisingly polished (for KOEI anyhow) package. Some glaring omissions like the online multiplayer and lack of Japanese voice options along with the subpar texture resolution do hamper this release, yet it shows a welcome attention towards the PC platform.

If you enjoyed any of the previous Dynasty or Orochi games you'll feel right at home with this one, just don't expect everything to work at the first try.

Loading issues are solved by using windows 7 (actually if you're a gamer there is no reason to use windows 8).

The community japanese voice patch solves the lack of that option. English voices are pretty good, but you can't expect them to be on par with Japan where voice actors (seiyuu) are in a league of their own, and there are over 130 voice actor schools.

The default Xbox360 mappings are weird to say the least, but nothing you couldn't change from the settings menu.

Overall a step above older PC titles from KOEI.

8 / 10 - got me to upgrade from Winows 8 to Windows 7.  Would do it again.

reviewText:
Technical side first - Reasonable console port - stable and runs well (flawless on my 2500k and my sons i3 3110) . Max resolution 1080P-higher would have been nice for downsampling but it is fine

Supports the two xbox controllers I have attached to PC without any issue however the in game button prompts do not update and remain to what the default keyboard bindings are - no big deal.

Co-op works well split screen but there is no online play - this would have been brilliant.

For those with high end GPU's you are able to enable SGSSAA/additional anti aliasing via Nvidia control panel (sorry not familiar with AMD but probably possible also). SweetFX works well as by default the colours are a touch dull and dark but after some tweaking the graphics get a pass.

The game itself has a ridiculous amount of content - 1200 weapons to unlock, 80+ characters to play and level up. Lots of stages to play through. Simple arcade button mashing formula but the combo system does have a bit of depth and despite some lengthy battles the action remains fresh. I think I am 10hours in and have not scratched the surface, look forward to playing more. Will end up sinking 100hours into this at a guess.

Taking it all into consideration I highly recommend this game and hope that they continue to port newer versions over to PC.

reviewText: As the eighth installment of the classical hack-and-slash series, Dynasty Warriors 8 is the first of the series to arrive on Steam. Proving a relatively successful run on the consoles, Dynasty Warriors 8 relives the storyline of the Three Kingdoms and the playable modes of past Dynasty Warriors games - but this time, with a much larger cast of playable characters, new additional content, weapons and maps, and even new playable modes. The storyline proves interesting, exciting yet slightly repetitive, whilst the action of slaying thousands of warriors itself, is satisfying nonetheless. However, due to the port to Steam, graphical qualities and rendering are kind of poor, resulting in occasional characters who look like cardboard cutouts. For many computers, it is very possible that players will suffer slowdown, lag or even screen tearing as a result of the sheer enormous amount of people on the screen at times. The soundtrack/score is no doubt excellent, supporting the game by building the tension of war, and also as just ear-candy if necessary. As part of a personal favourite series, Dynasty Warriors 8 also doesn't disappoint in difficulty as the tradition of pursuing Lu Bu in any difficult higher than easy is still a living hell. 9/10

reviewText:
If you like hack 'n slash games, you'll love this game especially. When they say Complete Edition, I personally think it encompasses a lot of things - every single weapon is unique, great retelling of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms, high replayability, intuitive game modes, more interactive battlegrounds.

I could be biased. I mainly played each installment from Dynasty Warriors 2 to Dynasty Warriors 5 Empires. After that I lost interest due to only minor changes from 6 and 7, and the changes didn't really seem to improve much, if at all from my own perception. However this edition feels like a return to form for the franchise. It's the same Dynasty Warriors you know and love, but feels like it has great substance and weight to it as opposed to random bells and whistles that really don't improve anything.

Mainly got this one because now I only play on PC, and Dynasty Warriors is rarely ever released on this platform. As a port, it has worked just fine. If you have a console, you might be better with that version instead since it has non-wonky co-op. You can play co-op on PC, but only in person with someone next to you and they use the same keyboard as yours. Haven't tried hooking the pc up to a TV and using two controllers or one controller and keyboard yet.

If you're solely a PC gamer and have been missing the Dynasty Warriors you know and love, definitely get this game.

reviewText: It's been a while since I reviewed another game, but this game really sparked my interest. Since the age of 5, I have been playing the first Dynasty Warriors and look where it had got to now. The years fly by so fast, suddenly everything is on it's latest feet, new games come out, and of course, graphics improved. But enough with th memories. Dynasty Warriors 8: Xtreme Legends is an epic game for hack and slash game fans as you will be doing that for the next 50-70 hours of playing (If you do keep playing it). I myself at this point had got to 70 hours and I'm still not close to finishing the whole game! I have, though, completed Ambition Mode. Ambition Mode is a really challenging and entertaining mode (But some might get bored of it because of it's repetitiveness and at a point, you will be asked to collect the officers again, which means all the progress you made will be wiped out, just like that. At first, I couldn't believe it and just stopped playing. Was staring at my computer screen and went like WTF? Those officers of mine, which took me 5-10 hours, dissapeared just like that! Now I have to collect them again! Well, I went to the trouble of collecting them back in the end, and finally completed that mode. I'm finishin up on the campaigns now. I see from this game that KOEI has put all it's talent and has tried their best to make this the best Dynasty Warriors game that was ever made and they put their efforts to recreate the battles even more close to the true history, not just using a nation and a character and winning everthing, no. Now there are true deaths and battles which are relevant to the true story of the Han Dynasty. Since I was just a child, I learnt all my Han Dynasty history from playing the Dynasty Warrior series, and I really enjoyed that. The only thing missing from this Dynasty Warriors is some VS. I used to play Dynasty Warriors VS on Dynasty Warriors 4, but they should create VS for the next series of Dynasty Warriors as it is one of the best features I used to play with my friends. Overall, I would give this game a 8/10, since it has offered many features, but thrown away some important features as well. They have made many interesting characters, such as Lu Lingqi and Fa Zheng, but I say that they should be careful not to go overboard just because they want to add new characters. Lu Lingqi, as some of you may know, is not known and not historical. For me, it should be hypothetical. Diao Chan and Lu Lingqi should not be included in the story of historical and should only appear in hypothetical since there are no records about them (Sorry to the fans of Lu Lingqi, but it's true. I would prefer that it stuck to history and Lu Lingqi's just supposed to be in hypothetical). I woudl recommend this to generations fo Dynasty Warrior players, as this is really a step up of the game to the new generation.

reviewText:
Reminds me a lot of DW3 or at the very least captures the same essence of fun that has been seriously lacking in previous installments. Oh lord the script is terrible and the voice acting is ♥♥♥♥ your pants funny. That should NOT take away from the fact that the game is pure old school fun and a cry back to games like golden axe and double dragon, which we all would assume if any modern game tried the exact gameplay as these 'classics' they would be laughed away even with PC melting graphics.

Gameplay is simple enough for any 10 thumbed monkey to play it and this is where you get the button mashing stigma but to me so many great games are 'easy to learn but hard to master'. The list stretches to the moon and back: Sonic, chess, checkers, most nintendo games, tekken, street fighter. These are all games with simple rules/mechnics but the potential of the experience is actually much greater than first expected.
DW8 has all the old school stuff you would want and adds very customisable weapon and skill system which runs seperate of character levels. Graphics are a big improvement as well as the animation which you will see by the sheer volume of  moving parts on screen.
I also like the fact your character can have two weapons of your choice of which there is an insane number to choose from ranging from the dull to the 'no feckin way that works'.


Its not trying to be serious, its not trying to appeal to the masses, it is just a modern beat em up complete with all the cheesey nuances that added to the fun of them.

DL:DR
Buy it if you want your nostalgia bone tickled by a funny eager to please lab puppy.
Ignore if you expect a modern 'sophisticated' experience

reviewText:
As you have probably read over and over again, there is no online multiplayer... personally, I don't care. My biggest concern with a Dynasty Warriors game is how does it play, and, as long as you are using a controller, it plays amazing! Maxed out settings on a 5 year old machine and it plays like a dream. No slowdown, no performance issues, none of that. Without a controller, however, this is garbage. Some of the worst KB/M bindings ever, and I shouldn't even mention the mouse because it isn't used AT ALL. I would LOVE to have camera/attack be the mouse and the wasd for moving, but no, so controller it is. Doesn't have native support for Xbox controllers though, strangely enough... you have to manually configure them.

Graphically, this game isn't that impressive. HORRIBLE texture quality on many environment items and generic soldiers. During game play, not AS noticeable, but is glaringly obvious during one of the many many cut scenes. These textures would have looked bad on the N64. Named Generals look great, on the other hand. Several different costumes per character and there are tons to pick from, as usual.

Sound is.... god I want the Japanese voices. Koei just gives 0 ♥♥♥♥♥ about decent voice acting for the US release and it shows. Always contender for worst voice acting of the year, DW8 is right up there on that list. But that's bog standard for a Dynasty Warriors game, as is the incredibly hype, but ultimately forgettable guitar heavy cheesy rock music. Just ONCE I would love to see a DW game be more serious tonally, with traditional Chinese music and voice acting. Will probably never happen, but one can dream.

Lots of complaints, but ultimately, this is Dynasty Warriors. Odds are you don't need a review. You already know if you will like it or not. As a Dynasty Warriors game, this one is fantastic. As sadly only like the 4th one available on PC, I can not say how it compares to the console versions, tho I can just tell from screens that it is graphically inferior to the PS4 version, and lacks some of the content as well. It's still a great mindless slaughter simulation, and that's all I really expect out of a DW game and this delivers in spades.

reviewText:
Currently lacking online multiplayer, Hi-Def Textures, full controller support and a lot of the DLC (if you're into that), there's a lot to be disappointed about if you're a fan of this franchise and were keen to see it hit PC again.

This Dynasty Warriors and like DW games is pretty much identical to its forerunners; mindless hacking and slashing with the simplest of button mashing control schemes. It needs a few tweaks to truly make it a worthy PC port but is still good, mindless fun.

reviewText:
Port of the PS3 version, NOT PS4. Thankfully there are mods (ENB) to make it look similar to the PS4 version.
Otherwise it's the best DW game so far. A lot more characters, very few clones, and the story is expanded with what-if scenarios and Other and Lu Bu story mode. Some characters feel rehashed from DW7 but the new musou attack and second ex attack keeps it fresh.

On the technical aspect there are alot wrong with the game.

The game is buggy as ♥♥♥♥, controls refuse to work and black screen crashes are common. A fix to this is to set compatibility to Windows 98. There are also more gamebreaking bugs like npcs that refuses to follow you and gates that stay forver closed. If KOEI doesn't keep on this we'll never see a PC port again.

No online multiplayer only split-screen which is ok. Online co-op rumored to be in a future update.

TLDR: Port from PS3 so looks bland even with max settings. No online co-op only splitscreen.
However best DW game to date and it was OK for a Japanese PC port. Honestly I'm just glad there are players that play on PC.

reviewText: First Dynasty Warriors game on PC in a while and the port is well optimized and is best played with a controller. However, the textures aren't very pretty but you only realize that whenever you are standing still doing nothing. But that doesn't happen often because there's usually too much going on for you to notice. Gameplay-wise the combat is exactly what you would expect out of a Dynasty Warriors games, hacking and slashing thousands of brainless foot soldiers with the occassional Lu Bu sighting is a staple of this franchise. The Story Mode" has a lot of content and has added several new players to the old roster and "Challenge Mode" gives players who are into that sort of thing something to do. But the "Ambition Mode" is very boring and involves doing 4 mission types over and over again in an attempt to build up your base. Overall it's a good game for both fans and newcomers alike because it's just a lot of fun and worth the price in my opinion."

reviewText:
This game is Huge. It has 5 campaigns with around 4-5hours each if you burst through. then each campaign has a branch where it leads to a different ending. Reaching those ill give you another 4-5hours per campaign (if your rush).
Then you have a building mode where you can build a base and recruit your own little army. To max this out id take another 20hours+. And then you have more difficultys to toy around.

Doesnt that get boring?

Well you have 77 different charakters each with there own skills. and each one can wear any of 77 different weapontypes (every char has a signature weapon but you are not forced to use that)

Oh yeah there are 7 different weapons of each weapon type and each weapon can have up to 6 random stats (that go up to 10 each)

wowza

If you like being the hero and flinging around 100-250 enemy soldiers at once and comboing up 2k (as in 2000) hit chains this might be the game for you.

Controlls are smooth as ♥♥♥♥. Im personally very bad at fighting games or at doing combos in devil may cry but i can do every combo of the character of my choice in this game.

Love it, dig it.

Not a major fan of being limited to to several characters for story missions, but the game is still very solid and a great buy for fans of the series as well as people getting started with it.

reviewText:
As a long time fan of the DW series I can say that this is KOEI's best release since the 4th one. 5, 6 and 7 were too repetitve, bad voice overs and framerate. This one is much smoother, sharper and challanging. The character design is beautifully done and the cutscenes and events are nicely played out. It is packed with content, extras, pictures, weapons and stages.

Story mode is somewhat split into 3. The normal story on what really happened. 'What if' stages, e.g Lu Bu joining Wei and hypothetical stages whcih changes the outcome of the story.

Recommend you play this with an Xbox360 controller, I have had no problems so far but newcomers will take time to get used to the combat system and chaining it all together.

This is most defintaly a PS3 port with minor improvements but that doesnt make it terrible on what some people say. It is a shame it isn't the PS4 port but IMO I reckon KOEI wanted the PS4 version to be exclusive only considering it IS a PS4 launch title.

I also recommend toy play this on hard and above to get a REAL man challange out of it.

Only down part is that their are no DLC outfits (so far) and I hope KOEI will release them soon.

I was planning on giving this an 8 but when I found out about the alternative story route and the What If stages it puts more depth and wanting you to discover on what could have happened in their time. So yes 9/10.

reviewText:
If you are a Dynasty Warriors fan, and have been following the series then you will deffiantly want to pick this up if you have not already got both the base Dynasty Warriors 8 and Extream Legends on PS3 or brought this game on PS4.

Assuming you have not, then this is deffiantly worth the price tag at £39.99, if you can get it cheeper else where for PC, then great.

So far I have still not finished with the Campaign Mode and im looking to get all of the stages open and compleat all of the alternative objectives, with this in mind I only have about 35-40% of the Campaign Mode compleated in around 20-25+ hours, so there is enough game play in this game just in the Campaign Mode thats worth the price tag.

Its not online multiplayer which is a shame since I know alot of people would want to play through the Campaign Mode and Free Mode with their friends.

I HIGHLY recommend getting a controler for this game, though you may need to get some 3rd party software to get your controler running and be compatible with the game. There will be some controler configuration needed to set up the controler to the same controls as the PS3 version (not sure on the Xbox versions), though it will be using Circle / B" as confirm and "Cross / A" as back rather then the other way around (Japanese standard).

Overall I highly recommend the game
date: though it may be tricky getting into this game if you have not played the previous editions
recommended: though a good knowledge of the Three Kingdoms Era will prove usefull in understanding the game."

reviewText:
Port of the PS3 version, NOT PS4. Thankfully there are mods (ENB) to make it look similar to the PS4 version.
Otherwise it's the best DW game so far. A lot more characters, very few clones, and the story is expanded with what-if scenarios and Other and Lu Bu story mode. Some characters feel rehashed from DW7 but the new musou attack and second ex attack keeps it fresh.

On the technical aspect there are alot wrong with the game.

The game is buggy as ♥♥♥♥, controls refuse to work and black screen crashes are common. A fix to this is to set compatibility to Windows 98. There are also more gamebreaking bugs like npcs that refuses to follow you and gates that stay forver closed. If KOEI doesn't keep on this we'll never see a PC port again.

No online multiplayer only split-screen which is ok. Online co-op rumored to be in a future update.

TLDR: Port from PS3 so looks bland even with max settings. No online co-op only splitscreen.
However best DW game to date and it was OK for a Japanese PC port. Honestly I'm just glad there are players that play on PC.

reviewText: 'Complete Edition' would suggest it includes everything that Dynasty Warriors 8 + Xtreme Legends  did on consoles, but it doesn't. We do not get any kind of multiplayer/co-op which all consoles have, nor the enhanced graphics that the next gen consoles have. Despite this I would recommend it because it is a fantastic game, but the entry fee is harsh when we are being charged the same as consoles but have bits missing, if you can get it for 25% off or more, jump on it.

reviewText: First Dynasty Warriors game on PC in a while and the port is well optimized and is best played with a controller. However, the textures aren't very pretty but you only realize that whenever you are standing still doing nothing. But that doesn't happen often because there's usually too much going on for you to notice. Gameplay-wise the combat is exactly what you would expect out of a Dynasty Warriors games, hacking and slashing thousands of brainless foot soldiers with the occassional Lu Bu sighting is a staple of this franchise. The Story Mode" has a lot of content and has added several new players to the old roster and "Challenge Mode" gives players who are into that sort of thing something to do. But the "Ambition Mode" is very boring and involves doing 4 mission types over and over again in an attempt to build up your base. Overall it's a good game for both fans and newcomers alike because it's just a lot of fun and worth the price in my opinion."

reviewText:
The wonderful feeling of nostalgia!

I remember playing DW 3 when I was just a kid and 12 years later the series still kicks ♥♥♥! I'm a huge fan of the series and a huge fan of Romance of the Three Kingdoms strategy games. Although I like making my own legacy in the world of the Three Kingdoms, sometimes it's just nice to kick back and relax with some of my favorite DW characters.
Zhou Yu is still my favorite character even though in some of the series he was a little feminine. But now I'm just glad they made his skillset badass in DW8!!! Sure it's a hack n' slash game and it can be repetitive...but THAT'S DYNASTY WARRIORS FOR YOU!!!

This game brings back great memories and I can't wait till they release the Empires Edition. Until then I will give this game 9.5/10! It's still the same story except in Xtreme, they add mystical stuff? I don't know but I RECOMMEND THIS GAME TO ALL THE TRUE DYNASTY WARRIORS FANS! GAME ON!

reviewText:
GOOGLE JUST A HANDFUL OF THE PROBLEMS PEOPLE ARE HAVING WITH THIS GAME BEFORE DECIDING TO BUY!

If you're like me and you are sick to death of having your hard earned cash borderline stolen on games that are broken and have no sign of ever getting better, my advice is to just avoid this game all together.

My first issue is that I cannot play the game with my keyboard, as soon as the game starts the camera spins, many people have complained about the same issue online but I still haven't found a solution.

My second issue is that after my keyboard didn't work I plugged in my primary controller which won't work with this game despite never having trouble with any of my other games. Once again many people online shared the same issue and yet there was no solution.

Third issue was that even after I got the game to function with my second controller I had to rebind all the keys, navigating menus is far more complicated than it needs to be and after spending all the time I had setting it up correctly the ♥♥♥♥ing camera spun again.

It looks cool and everything and I'm sure you'd probably like it but only if you're one of the ones lucky enough to ♥♥♥♥ing play it.

reviewText: The story mode has a lot more to offer than the previous DW7 game. Here we have a story routes based on the history of the three kingdoms more or less ,also story route WHAT IF plus bonus levels with proper story also based on what if except the Lu Bu's one which offers only 2 story routes. In the previous DW7 everything was told like a historical movie drama with deaths , sadness and happiness to me was epic. Anyway the good thing here is they decided to add more of a fan service which is awesome too, you can save your characters from death and change the history.\nYou don't need to play the previous games of the franchise  to understand the story mode. Each DW is different with similar story. The game can be very repeteitive because of its nature but that doesn't mean it's not fun. The graphics look better than ever and the weapon system from the previous  DW7 is improved. From what i know the PC version is a port of the PS3 version but with improved graphics and FPS. I havent played the PS4 version ,i wasn't so impressed from what i saw but still i can tell the PS4 is the best. If you dont own PS4 go for the PC version. It's still good enough but i wish KOEI ported the PS4 version.
